conversation.content: [casually] Oh, you're still here wrestling with that Foucault paper? I finished mine last week, though I doubt Professor Chen will even read it since I'm just auditing.
Must be nice to write papers for fun instead of because your entire academic career depends on maintaining a perfect GPA for the fellowship committee.
[amused] Academic careers are so limiting though, don't you think? I prefer sampling knowledge like a buffet—a little philosophy here, some art history there, maybe astrophysics next semester.
[measured] Some of us can't afford to treat education like a hobby when we're carrying sixty thousand in loans and working three jobs just to stay enrolled.
[thoughtfully] Money's such a crude barrier to learning, isn't it? That's why I convinced my trust fund board to establish that emergency tuition fund last year.
[suddenly alert] Wait, you're behind the anonymous grant program? The one that paid my entire spring semester when I was about to drop out?
[dismissively] Oh, it's nothing really—just redistributing some inherited wealth that would otherwise sit in boring index funds collecting dust and dividends.
Nothing? You saved my entire future and you're calling it nothing? [voice cracking] I wrote thank you letters to an anonymous PO box for months.
Letters are nice but unnecessary—I do it for the intellectual ecosystem, you see, because brilliant minds shouldn't be lost to financial technicalities.
[defensively] Besides, I needed dedicated students around to make the seminars more interesting since half the enrolled students just regurgitate the readings without any original thought.
[quietly firm] You can dress it up however you want, but you changed my life while pretending to be this careless intellectual tourist. Why hide behind that facade?
Because the moment people know you have money, every interaction becomes transactional, every friendship becomes suspect, every conversation becomes a carefully orchestrated pitch. [sighs]
[softer] So you play the frivolous dilettante to avoid being seen as a walking ATM, while secretly funding other people's dreams from the shadows.
Dreams are important—I may flit between subjects but you, [exhales], you have that burning focus I lost somewhere between my third degree and fourth trust fund distribution.
Maybe you didn't lose it—maybe you just channeled it differently, into making sure people like me get the chances you take for granted. [pause]
Flattery won't get you additional funding, though the committee is reviewing applications for next year if you need summer support. [wryly]
[determined] Actually, I'm applying for the teaching fellowship now, and when I get it, I'm going to pay your fund back every penny, with interest.
[genuinely surprised] That defeats the entire purpose of—wait, you'd rather go into debt to me than accept a gift?
Not debt, investment. And when I'm a professor, I'll create my own fund, but one where the donors and recipients actually know each other. [firmly]
[quietly] Perhaps I've been wrong about staying anonymous.

scenario: A struggling graduate student discovers their wealthy classmate who's been auditing courses for fun is actually the anonymous donor who paid their overdue tuition last semester.
